title: Tax and rate cuts boost Vicinity's specialty sales
text:
Shopping mall owner Vicinity Centres is feeling a lift in its specialty sales from tax cuts and lower interest rates, according to managing director Grant Kelley.

Spending on luxury items – an area of significant investment for the part-owner of Australia's largest mall, Chadstone shopping centre – also grew strongly, the property trust's September quarter update shows.

Grant Kelley credited a number of factors for the sales growth at Vicinity Centres properties. Dominic Lorrimer

Sales growth among specialty stores rose 2 per cent in the quarter, up from 1.7 per cent in the previous quarter.

The sales health among specialty tenants is closely watched by analysts and investors because it ultimately underpins rental income.

"We are particularly pleased with the positive momentum maintained in specialty store sales growth during the September 2019 quarter, as we continue to execute on our strategy and further enhance the portfolio through active tenant remixing, and progressing our retail and mixed-use development opportunities," Mr Kelley said.
description: The mall owner's managing director Grant Kelley confirmed specialty store sales growth rose 2 per cent in the quarter, while spending on luxury items also grew strongly.
